column1: Shendi or Shandi (شندى) is a town in northern Sudan
column2: situated on the east bank of the Nile River 150 km northeast of Khartoum. Shandi is also about 45 km southwest of the ancient city of Meroe. Located in the River Nile wilayah
column3: Shandi is the center of the Ja'aliin tribe and an important historic trading center. Its principal suburb on the west bank is Al-Matamma. A major traditional trade route across the Bayuda Desert connects Al-Matamma to Marawi and Napata
column4: 250 km to the northwest. The town is the historical capital of the powerful arabised Nubian Ja'alin tribe whom most of its denizens belong to.

column1: Very basic services and infrastructure mean that Shendi exists mainly as a center for trade in agricultural goods from nearby farms.
Roads have begun to be laid cross the city. The railway station in the city is no longer used for passenger travel
column2: although freight trains continue to use the tracks. Shendi is home to an airport (ICAO code HSND).

A UNESCO funded center exists within the town to promote education in foreign languages and Information Technology.
